data.text: Has Anyone Made a DIY Crank Tank
Has anyone made a DIY cranktank?
Imho bladder is way better option.
data.author: Daniel Dziku Zalewski

data.text: the tube and quick connect suggests that there is a bladder inside...What are you trying to say?
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: i have a cranktank with no separate bladder on the inside. i think theyre trying to say a bladder is collapsible when no water is in it so it saves more space to have a full frame bag with a bladder on the inside. however i prefer to use a crank tank, i just like it
data.author: Christian Ramos

data.text: I never understood that argument... You still have to save that room in your frame bag for when you fill it back up...
data.author: Zeno Molteni

data.text: if you were riding thru desert youd fill up your bladder all the way. if you made it into the mountains and its cold and rainy you probably wouldnt need as much water. so bladder takes up less space when half full, and you can use the now extra space for more food, or maybe a piece of clothing u just got at the store

data.text:
You could always seal the inside with silicone. There are food-safe PLAs that could be used for final product after prototyping. https://all3dp.com/2/food-safe-filament-brands-compared/

data.text: Haha, that amount is next to nothing in many parts of the world beyond Great Divide Route. I had 16 litres on the Puna and 13 litres in Namibia and Australia for exempel.

data.text: yeah, I had 13L in the Bolivian Altiplano. In the end it was more than we needed but it's the uncertainty of water supply points that means you need to carry lots.

data.author: Adie Mitchell

data.text:
Yeah I was going on a map a backpacking.com map. And it said there was water but I couldn‚Äôt find. It was only my third day riding and I completely overestimated how far I could get. I completely underestimated how rough the route was gonna beÔøº. Luckily when I got up the next morning I saw in the distance some pondÔøºs near 100s of Llamas and alpacas grazing. I normally probably wouldn‚Äôt have drank that water even having filtered, but I had no choice. Long story short I was OK water was fine and I learned a very valuable lesson. ÔøºÔøºÔøº

data.author: Zeno Molteni

data.text: I'm all about DIYing things, but for the hassle I think buying the real thing might be the better option in this case
data.author: Zeno Molteni

data.text: So I've bought and used extensively the 4L and have ordered the 3L (tank only because it's compatible with 4L fittings). I've done the bladder in a frame bag thing too, and it's simply not the same. The lack of slop and how efficiently the cranktank uses space can't be beaten. Also, I hate to the point of dry reaching that horrible plastic taste... but have never experienced it with the cranktank. Granted, if you have stuff lying about gathering dust you might want to use that first, but if you're buying afresh because you are starting without the necessary hydration equipment, cranktanks are cheaper/lighter/ bigger than most options. I especially like how I could easily add a quick release near the bite valve, then use a cnoc-befree setup as a direct-to-cranktank gravity filter system. Admittedly, I'm in New Zealand so the postage isn't too much of a problem - one of the most substantial disadvantages is getting a cranktank sent to northern hemisphere.
data.author: Brad Coombes
